column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=PART.
#Text=III.
#Text=An offer at the Improvement, and Melioration of the Aer of LONDON, by way of Plantations, &c.
#Text=THere goes a pleasant Tale of a certain Sr Politick, that in
#Text=the last great Plague projected, how by a Vessel fraight with
#Text=peel ' d Onions, which should passe along the Thames by the City,
#Text=when the Wind fate in a favourable quarter, to attract the pollution
#Text=of the Aer, and sail away with the Infection to the Sea:
#Text=Transplantation of Diseases we sometimes read of amongst the
#Text=Magneticall, or rather Magical Cures; but never before of this
#Text=way of Transfretation: but, however this excellent conceit
#Text=has often afforded good mirth on the Stage, and I now mention
#Text=to prevent the application to what I hope propound; There is yet
#Text=another expedient, which I have here to offer (were This of
#Text=the poisonous and filthy smoak remov ' d) by which the City and
#Text=environs about it, might be rendred one of the most pleasant
#Text=and agreeable places in the world.
#Text=In order to this I
#Text=propose.
#Text=That all low-grounds circumjacent to the City, especially
#Text=East and South-west, be cast and contriv ' d into square plots, or
#Text=Fields of twenty, thirty, and forty Akers, or more, separated
#Text=from each others by Fences of double Palisads, or Contr ' spaliers,
#Text=which should enclose a Plantation of an hundred and fifty, or
#Text=more, feet deep, about each Field; not much unlike to what His
#Text=Majesty has already begun by the wall from Old Spring-garden
#Text=to St.
#Text=Iames ' s in that Park; and is somewhat resembled in the
#Text=new Spring-garden at Lambeth.
#Text=That these Palisad ' s be elegantly
#Text=planted, diligently kept and supply ' d, with such Shrubs,
#Text=as yield the most fragrant and odoriferous Flowers, and are aptest
#Text=to tinge the Aer upon every gentle emission at a great distance:
#Text=Such as are (for instance amongst many others) the Sweet-brier,
#Text=all the Periclymena ' s and Woodbinds; the Common white and
#Text=yellow Iessamine, both the Syringa ' s or Pipe trees; the Guelder-Rose,
#Text=the Musk, and all other Roses; Genista Hispanica: To
#Text=these may be added the Rubus odoratus, Bayes, Iuniper, Lignum-vitae,
#Text=Laevander: but above all, Rosemary, the Flowers
#Text=whereof are credibly reported to give their sent above thirty
#Text=Leagues off at Sea, upon the coasts of Spain: and at some distance
#Text=towards the Meadow side, Vines, yea, Hops.
#Text=—Et Arbuta passim,*
#Text=Et Glaucas Salices, Casiamque Crocumque rebentem,
#Text=Et pinguem Tiliam, & ferrugineos Hyacinthos, &c.
#Text=For, there is a very sweet smelling Sally, and the blossoms of
#Text=the Tilia or Lime-tree, are incomparably fragrant; in brief,
#Text=whatsoever is odoriferous and refreshing.
#Text=That the Spaces, or Aera between these Palisads, and Fences,
#Text=be employ ' d in Beds and Bordures of Pinks, Carnations, Clove,
#Text=Stock-gilly-flower, Primroses, Aurieulds, Violets, not forgetting
#Text=the White, which are in flower twice a year, April and August:
#Text=
#Text=Cowslips, Lillies, Nareissus, Strawberries, whose very leaves as
#Text=well as fruit, emit a Cardiaque, and most refreshing Halitus: also
#Text=Parietaria Lutea, Musk, Lemmon, and Mastick, Thyme: Spike,
#Text=Cammomile, Balm, Mint, Marjoram, Pempernel, and Serpillum,
#Text=&c. which upon the least pressure and cutting, breathe out and
#Text=betray their ravishing odors.
#Text=That the Fields, and Crofts within these Closures, or Invironing
#Text=Gardens, be, some of them, planted with wild Thyme, and
#Text=others reserved for Plots of Beans, Pease (not Cabbages, whose
#Text=rotten and perishing stalks have a very noisom and unhealthy
#Text=smell, and therefore by Hyppocrates utterly condemned near
#Text=great Cities) but such blossom-bearing Grain as send forth their
#Text=virtue at farthest distance, and are all of them marketable at
#Text=London; by which means, the Aer and Winds perpetually fann ' d
#Text=from so many circling and encompassing Hedges, fragrant Shrubs,
#Text=Trees, and Flowers (the amputation and prunings of whose superfluities,
#Text=may in Winter, on some occasions of weather, and
#Text=winds, be burnt, to visit the City with a more benign smoak) not
#Text=onely all that did approach the Region, which is properly design ' d
#Text=to be Flowery; but even the whole City, would be sensible
#Text=of the sweet and ravishing varieties of the perfumes, as well
#Text=as of the most delightful and pleasant objects, and places of
#Text=Recreation for the Inhabitants; yielding also a Prospect of a noble
#Text=and masculine Majesty, by reason of the frequent plantations
#Text=of Trees, and Nurseries for Ornament, Profit, and Security:
#Text=The remainder of the Fields included, yielding the same, and
#Text=better Shelter, and Pasture for Sheep and Cattel then now;
#Text=that they lie bleak, expos ' d and abandon ' d to the winds, which
#Text=perpetually invade them.
#Text=That, to this end, the Gardiners (which now cultivate the
#Text=upper, more drie and ungrateful soil) be encouraged to begin
#Text=Plantations in such places onely: and the farther exorbitant encrease
#Text=of Tenements, poor and nasty Cottages near the City,
#Text=be prohibited, which disgrace and take off from the sweetness
#Text=and amoenity of the Environs of London, and are already become
#Text=a great Eye-sore in the grounds opposite to His Majesty ' s
#Text=Palace of White hall; which being converted to this use,
#Text=might yield a diversion inferior to none that could be imagin ' d
#Text=
#Text=for Health, Profit, and Beauty, which are the three Transcendencies
#Text=that render a place without all exception.
#Text=And
#Text=this is what (in short) I had to offer, for the Improvement and
#Text=Melioration of the Aer about London, and with which I shall
#Text=conclude this discourse.
#Text=FINIS.
